it.unimi.dsi.law.util
Class ExchangeCounter

java.lang.Object
  it.unimi.dsi.law.util.ExchangeCounter

public class ExchangeCounter
extends Object

Computes the number of discordances between two orders using Knight's n log n MergeSort-based algorithm.

The number of discordances between two orders is the number of pairs whose mutual relationship is opposite in the two orders (ties are not counted).

The computation of the number of discordances is the most onerous step in the computation of Kendall's τ (in that case, the two orders are induced by two lists of ranks). It is possible to compute the number of discordances trivially using BubbleSort and counting the exchanges that are necessary to complete the sorting, but Knight noted that the same can be done in time O(n log n) using a stable sorting algorithm (William R. Knight, A Computer Method for Calculating Kendall's Tau with Ungrouped Data, J. Amer. Statist. Assoc., vol. 61, N. 314, 1966, pages 436−439).

This class allows to count the number of exchanges that will change a given order, specified by an array of integers, into another order, specified by an IntComparator. You must creates an exchange counter first, and then invoke count(). You are welcome to use a one-liner (e.g., new ExchangeCounter(v, c).count()), so that the large support array allocated by an instance of this class is collected quickly. Optionally, you can pass a support array explicitly.

The slightly awkward structure is due to the necessity (in the computation of Kendall's τ) of computing the first order externally, and to avoid passing around several additional parameters in recursive calls.

Constructor Detail

ExchangeCounter

public ExchangeCounter(int[] a,
                       IntComparator c,
                       int[] support)
Creates a new exchange counter with given array and comparator, using a given support array.

This constructor avoids the need to allocate a support array, in case one is already available.

Parameters:
a - the array to be sorted.
c - the comparator to be used.
support - an array that will be used as temporary storage during the computation (its content will be erased); must be at least as long as a.

ExchangeCounter

public ExchangeCounter(int[] a,
                       IntComparator c)
Creates a new exchange counter with given array and comparator.

Parameters:
a - the array to be sorted.
c - the comparator to be used.
Method Detail

count

public long count()
Computes the number of exchanges for the current data.

Note that a call to this method will actually order the array provided at creation time using the comparator provided at creation time; thus, subsequent calls will always return 1.

Returns:
the number of exchanges that will order the vector provided at creation time using the comparator provided at creation time.
